The sluggish kinetics of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and high over potential of oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are big challenges in the development of high-performance zinc-air batteries (ZABs) and fuel cells. In this work, we report a rational design and a simple fabrication strategy of a photo-enhanced Co single-atom catalyst (SAC) comprising g-C3N4 coupled with cobalt-nitrogen-doped hierarchical mesoporous carbon (Co-N/MPC), forming a staggered p-n heterojunction that effectively improves charge separation and enhances electrocatalytic activity. The incorporation of Co SACs and g-C3N4 synergistically optimizes the photogenerated electron-hole pair separation, significantly boosting the intrinsic ORR-OER duplex activity. Under illumination, g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC exhibits an outstanding ORR half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.841 V (vs. RHE) in 0.1 mol L–1 KOH and a low OER overpotential of 497.4 mV (vs. RHE) at 10 mA cm–2 in 1 mol L–1 KOH. Notably, the catalyst achieves an exceptional peak power density of 850.7 mW cm–2 in ZABs and of 411 mW cm–2 even in H2-air fuel cell. In addition, g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC-based ZABs also show remarkable cycling stability exceeding 250 h. The advanced photo-induced charge separation at the p-n heterojunction facilitates faster electron transfer kinetics, and the mass transport owing to hierarchical mesoporous structure of Co-N-C, thereby reducing the overpotential and enhancing the overall energy conversion efficiency. This work provides a new perspective on designing next-generation of single-atom dispersed oxygen reaction catalysts, paving the way for high-performance photo-enhanced energy storage and conversion systems. Keywords Co single-atom Hierarchical mesoporous carbon Photo-enhancement p-n Heterojunction Oxygen catalytic reaction 1 Introduction The continuous depletion of fossil fuels and the resulting environmental pollution have motivated researchers to seek clean and highly efficient technologies for energy storage and conversion [1–3]. Rechargeable zinc-air batteries (ZABs) hold great promise as a large-scale energy storage solution, owing to their high energy density (1084 Wh kg–1) [4,5], low cost and environmental sustainability. Similarly, fuel cells, particularly proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs), have emerged as a key technology for clean energy conversion due to their high efficiency and zero-emission operation [6,7]. However, the widespread adoption of PEMFCs is hindered by the high cost and limited durability of platinum-based catalysts, especially for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) at the cathode [8]. Despite significant progress in the development of bifunctional catalysts in recent years, the sluggish kinetics of the ORR in fuel cells and high over potential of oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in ZABs pose significant challenges to long-term cycling stability and high efficiency [9,10]. In this regard, photo-enhanced bifunctional catalysts harness absorbed light energy to produce electron-hole pairs, with the resulting electrons and holes driving the ORR and OER, respectively, which helps reduce the overall overpotential [11–13]. Additionally, heterojunctions formed by photocatalysts play a critical role in minimizing electron-hole recombination, thus improving charge separation and enhancing transport efficiency [14,15]. Therefore, it is essential to develop a cost-effective, durable, and highly efficient bifunctional photo-electrocatalyst for the ORR and OER to significantly accelerate the electrochemical kinetics. Metal-nitrogen-doped carbon (M-N-C) catalysts have garnered significant attention with their advantages in active sites, modification, and conductive network [16–18]. In particular, Co-N-C single-atom catalysts (SACs) have exhibited promising duplex oxygen catalytic activity (for example, both for ORR and OER), attributed to their abundant and highly active Co-N x sites [19–22]. Nevertheless, Co-N-C catalysts based on traditional carbon supports still remind certain challenges: (1) uneven dispersion on the substrate, which reduces the effective number of active sites and limits catalytic activity; (2) leaching or detachment of Co atoms and particle growth and Ostwald ripening, leading to the aggregation of active sites and a decline in electrochemical surface area [23]; and (3) carbon support corrosion under electrochemical conditions, resulting in structural instability and performance decay [24,25]. Compared to traditional carbon black supports (e.g., Vulcan XC-72), hierarchical mesoporous carbon (MPC) offers several advantages as a support material for Co-N-C catalysts, enhancing their stability, activity, and durability in electrochemical applications such as fuel cells and metal-air batteries [26]. These advantages include that: (1) the high surface area enhances active sites dispersion and active site utilization, showing high electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) [27]; (2) the interconnected porous structure of MPC reduces the mobility mitigation of nanoparticle growth and Ostwald ripening [28]; (3) the hierarchical pore structure (micropores, mesopores, and macropores) facilitates mass transport and reactant diffusion, improving overall reaction kinetics [29,30]; and (4) the robust carbon framework with superior corrosion resistance minimizes structural collapse, exhibiting high structural stability. In addition, the interconnected carbon network provides an efficient electron transport pathway, reducing internal resistance and improving charge transfer during electrocatalysis [31,32]. Thus, utilizing MPC as support for synthesizing high-performance Co-N-C single-atom catalysts offers significant advantages [33,34]. On the other hand, graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) serves as a cost-effective photocatalyst, featuring abundant covalent C-N bonds, a moderate bandgap, and high chemical stability [35]. The incorporation of g-C3N4 can greatly improve stability and performance by offering anchoring sites to inhibit Co aggregation, strengthening structural integrity, and facilitating electron-hole pair generation under illumination to accelerate the kinetics of both ORR and OER [36,37]. This approach not only maintains an optimal C/N ratio but also enhances the overall catalytic efficiency and durability of the Co-N/MPC system [38,39]. In this work, we successfully synthesized g-C3N4@Co-N/ MPC, a high-performance photo-enhanced bifunctional catalyst, via a high-energy ball-milling (HEBM) process, coupling g-C3N4 with Co-N/MPC. The well-defined porous structure of Co-N/MPC serves as an efficient charge and mass transport network, while the layered g-C3N4 significantly enhances light absorption and photogenerated charge separation. The formation of a staggered p-n heterojunction between g-C3N4 and Co-N/MPC facilitates efficient electron transfer, thereby minimizing electron-hole recombination and enhancing the catalytic kinetics of both ORR and OER. As a result, g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC achieves outstanding ORR/OER bifunctionality, characterized by a low overpotential (ΔE) of 0.8864 V. When integrated into zinc-air batteries, the catalyst exhibits an exceptional peak power density (850.7 mW cm–2), an excellent specific capacity (718.3 mAh gZn –1), and long-term durability over 250 h. Specifically, g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC also realizes a very high power density even in H2-air fuel cell. This study demonstrates a novel and scalable strategy for designing photo-enhanced bifunctional catalysts, advancing the development of highly stable and efficient zinc-air batteries and photo-enhanced fuel cells. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Cobalt (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O), SiO2 (PS = 500 nm), Potassium hydroxide (KOH) and Sodium hydroxide (NaOH) were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. PQ-7 (Polyquaternium-7,10%) was purchased from Shanghai YuanYe Biotechnology Co., Ltd. Hydrochloric acid (HCl), sulphuric acid (H2SO4) were obtained from Hu Shi Co., Ltd. 20% Pt/C and IrO2 were obtained from Johnson Matthey. 2.2 The synthesis of g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC The g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC was synthesized through the coupling of g-C3N4 and Co-N/MPC, as illustrated in Fig. 1(a) . g-C3N4 was generated via thermal processing of urea at 550 °C for 3 h with a heating rate of 3 °C min–1. And the Co-N/MPC was primarily synthesized using the hard template method. In detail, the precursor solution was prepared by mixing PQ-7(10 wt%), SiO2, Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.1 mol L–1 HCl in a mass ratio of 9:2:3:36, and was dried and subsequently heated to 800 °C for 60 min with a heating rate of 20 °C min–1 in a N2 atmosphere to achieve primary carbonization. Thereafter, the material underwent sequential alkaline (4 mol L–1 NaOH) and acid washing (0.5 mol L–1 H2SO4) processing to remove the nano-silica template and other residual impurities. Finally, the washed material was subjected to secondary carbonization, resulting in Co-N/MPC. The g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC was obtained by ball-milling a mixture of g-C3N4 with Co-N/MPC (the mass ratio of g-C3N4: Co-N/MPC = 0.3:1) at 300 rpm for 480 min. For comparison, g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC(0.1:1), g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC(0.2:1), and g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC(0.4:1) were prepared under the same conditions but with altered mass ratios of g-C3N4 to Co-N/MPC (0.1:1, 0.2:1 and 0.4:1, respectively). 2.3 Characterization To investigate the morphology and structure of the synthesized sample, Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, S-4800), transmission electron microscope (TEM, 200 kV) and high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) with the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) analysis capability were utilized. X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8) was used to identify the crystalline phases of the synthesized catalyst. The elemental analysis was characterized using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Escalab 250Xi). The specific surface area and pore characteristics of the synthesized catalyst were measured using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET). Raman spectroscopy (InVia-Reflex) was employed to analyze the chemical structure and defects. The X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectroscopy was employed in identifying the oxidation states of the elements. The Fourier-transformed extended X-ray absorption fine structure (FT-EXAFS) spectra were applied to characterize the local environment and coordination structure of the Co site. Ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) spectroscopy (UV3600) was conducted using a continuous light source in the range of 200–800 nm to generate characteristic absorption spectra of the sample. 2.4 Photoelectrochemical performance testing All photoelectrochemical tests were conducted using a CHI760D electrochemical workstation in a conventional three-electrode system. The catalyst ink was prepared by dispersing 2 mg of catalyst in a solution containing 400 μL of isopropanol and 100 μL of 0.1 wt% Nafion, followed by 40 min of ultrasonication. Subsequently, the ink was applied to a glassy carbon electrode (GCE) at a volume of 9.8 μL and allowed to dry, achieving a catalyst loading of 200 μg cm–2. This formed the working electrode (WE). Meanwhile, the platinum wire serves as the counter electrode and a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) acts as the reference electrode. For comparison, an ink formulated with commercial Pt/C (20 wt% Pt) and IrO2 were evaluated under identical conditions. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) tests and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were performed using a rotating disk electrode (RDE). The ORR/OER tests were conducted at a scan rate of 5 mV s–1 and a rotation speed of 1600 rpm, under both illuminated and dark state. The ORR tests were evaluated in an O2-saturated 0.1 mol L–1 KOH electrolyte with the potential range from 0–1.1 V (vs. RHE), and the OER tests were carried out in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH from 1.1–1.9 V (vs. RHE), respectively. 2.5 Photo enhanced Zn-air battery and fuel cell The zinc-air battery with a homemade mode, where a polish zinc plate functions as the anode, a catalyst-loaded (g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC loading: 2 mg cm–2) carbon paper as the cathode (air electrode), and 6 M KOH as the electrolyte. All ZABs testing was conducted by LAND testing system under a xenon lamp (CEL-PE300L-3A) with 1-sunlight illumination. For the fuel cell, the anode (hydrogen electrode) and cathode (oxygen electrode) were prepared with catalyst loadings of 0.1 mgPt cm–2 and 2.0 mg cm–2, respectively, on a 2×2 cm2 electrode area (total area of 4 cm2). A Gore™ membrane with a thickness of 8 μm was used as the separator. The gas flow rates were set to 400 mL min–1 for hydrogen and 1000 mL min–1 for air. The operating temperature was maintained at 80 °C. The performance of the cells was evaluated under both illuminated and non-illuminated conditions using a xenon lamp (CEL-PE300L-3A) with 1-sunlight intensity. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physical and chemical characterization The synthesis procedure for g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC was illustrated in Fig. 1(a). The incorporation of PQ-7 molecules, enriched with quaternary ammonium groups, enables tunable nitrogen doping, facilitating the in-situ one-step synthesis of a hierarchical mesoporous nitrogen-doped carbon (MPC) framework. The calcination process is crucial for constructing a well-defined hierarchical mesoporous structure, while subsequent alkaline and acidic leaching steps ensure the complete removal of residual organic and inorganic species. This results in the formation of a cobalt-nitrogen-doped hierarchical mesoporous structure (Co-N/MPC) architecture with enhanced physicochemical stability and electrochemical properties. To further optimize catalytic performance, mechanochemical ball-milling is employed, leveraging high-energy shear forces to achieve uniform and intimate integration of g-C3N4 with Co-N/MPC, ultimately yielding the g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC catalyst. Fig. 1(b) and Figs. S1(a)–(c) reveal that Co-N/MPC exhibits a high density of hierarchically distributed pores with diameters ranging from 0.5 to 40 nm (Fig. S2), resulting in an exceptionally high specific surface area (SSA) of 891.304 m2 g–1. The multilayered lamellar structure of g-C3N4 (Figs. S1(d)–(f) provides abundant accessible interfaces, facilitating seamless integration with the porous carbon network (Fig. S3). Atomic-scale structural insights obtained via high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM, Fig. 1(c) confirm the uniform dispersion of atomically dispersed Co sites within the g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC framework. Furthermore, the TEM image (Fig. 1(e) reveals a well-preserved porous carbon architecture, where g-C3N4 layers are tightly interwoven with Co-N/MPC, exhibiting no discernible interfacial gaps-indicative of strong electronic and structural interactions. High-resolution TEM (HRTEM, Fig. 1(f) further corroborates the presence of well-defined graphitic lattice fringes, showing high structural stability as well as high electrical conductivity. Finally, elemental mapping via EDS (Fig. 1(d) demonstrates the homogeneous distribution of C, N, and Co, confirming the successful synthesis of the designed heterostructure. As illustrated in Fig. 2(a) , the XRD patterns of g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC closely resemble those of Co-N/MPC. Two broad diffraction peaks centered at 25° and 43° were observed, corresponding to the (002) and (103) reflections of graphitized carbon, respectively. This suggests an amorphous carbon structure without well-defined crystalline domains. Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 2(b) further corroborates this observation, with g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC exhibiting an I D/I G ratio of 1.07, comparable to that of Co-N/MPC (1.08), indicating that the degree of graphitization and defect density remains largely unchanged following g-C3N4 incorporation (Fig. S4) [40]. Additionally, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution analysis (Fig. S2) reveals that g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC retains a type-IV isotherm, indicative of a well-developed mesoporous network similar to that of Co-N/MPC. Despite this structural similarity, g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC exhibits a SSA of 584.95 m2 g–1, lower than that of Co-N/MPC. The reduction of SSA may stem from topological defect formation during the thermal treatment process, which is employed to remove residual heteroatoms from the carbon framework. By extending the “size effect” to pore size variation, it is clear that hierarchical porosity and interfacial interactions are more decisive for catalytic activity than SSA alone, as they optimize active site utilization, charge transfer, and mass transport dynamics [41,42]. The presence of significant carbon defects in g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC is further evidenced by the hysteresis loop observed in the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and the increased intensity of the D-band in the Raman spectrum [43,44]. To gain further insights into the chemical composition and electronic structure of the catalyst, XPS analysis was performed (Figs. 2(c), (d)). The high-resolution C 1s spectra of Co-N/MPC and g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC reveal four primary peaks at 284.8 eV (C-C), 286.4 eV (C-N/C=N), 288.4 eV (C=O), and 291 eV (π-π*), where the peak at 291 eV originates from aromatic ring vibrations, indicative of π-π interactions [45,46]. The N 1s spectrum (Fig. 2(d) further confirms the presence of five distinctive nitrogen species, including pyridinic N (398.6 eV), Co-N (399.6 eV), pyrrolic N (400.5 eV), graphitic N (401.2 eV), and oxidized N (403 eV). Notably, Fig. 2(e) and Table S1 reveal that the introduction of g-C3N4 leads to a higher prevalence of pyridinic N (27.63%), Co-N (17.89%) and graphitic N species (32.73%), which play a pivotal role in enhancing catalyst activity/stability and electronic conductivity, respectively [47]. In general, the presence of Co-N coordination centers, which exhibit higher stability relative to other metal-ligand structures, is crucial for sustaining high catalytic performance across a broad range of reaction conditions [48,49]. Additionally, the increased fraction of graphitic N enhances the electronic conductivity and thermal stability of the catalyst, further improving its electrocatalytic efficiency (Fig. S5) [50,51]. To elucidate the local coordination environment of cobalt species, XAFS spectroscopy was conducted. XANES analysis (Fig. 2(f) indicates that the oxidation state of Co in g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC closely aligns with that of CoPc, suggesting a Co valence state of approximately +2. Moreover, the Fourier transform of the k 3-weighted EXAFS spectra (Figs. 2(g), S6, S7 and Table S2) demonstrates a distinct Co-N peak at ~1.5 Å, confirming that Co atoms predominantly exhibit first-shell Co-N coordination. Quantitative EXAFS fitting further supports the presence of Co-N4 single-atom coordination sites, indicative of atomically dispersed Co centers [52,53]. To further probe the coordination environment of Co species, the wavelet transform (WT) spectra of Co K-edge EXAFS was conducted (Fig. 2(h). The WT contour plot shows a single intensity maximum at 6 Å–1, corresponding to Co-N coordination, with no additional features indicative of Co–Co bonding. This observation unequivocally confirms that g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC predominantly comprises atomically dispersed Co active sites, characteristic of a single-atom catalyst (SAC) structure and aligning well with the HAADF-STEM results [54,55]. 3.2 Photo-enhanced ORR/OER electrocatalytic performance The ORR activity of all catalysts was systematically evaluated under an O2-saturated 0.1 mol L–1 KOH electrolyte under both light and dark conditions. To further investigate the photo-electrocatalytic properties, Figs. 3(a), (b) and Table S3 show that g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC achieves a half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.841 V under illumination. These values are comparable to that of Co-N/MPC (0.847 V) and the 20% Pt/C+IrO2(1:1) catalyst mixture (0.845 V), and but significantly higher than their respective performances in dark conditions (Fig. S8 and Fig. S9(a). In addition, that g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC shows a higher limiting current density of 5.70 mA cm–2 than g-C3N4 (2.73 mA cm–2), Co-N/MPC (4.98 mA cm–2, Fig. 3(b) and other ratios samples (Fig. S9(a) under illumination. This finding highlights the synergistic effect between g-C3N4 and Co-N/MPC (Fig. 3(b), which plays a pivotal role in enhancing ORR performance. The high-performance of g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC also is further verified by its small ohmic resistance (R ohmic) of 1.83 Ω cm2, revealing the fast electron transfer pathway, and its small charge-transfer resistance (R ct: 4.84 Ω cm2) and low Tafel slope (69.7 mV dec–1, Fig. 3(c), and Fig. S9 (c), showing the quick reaction kinetic [56,57]. To elucidate the ORR reaction mechanism, the electron transfer number (n) was determined via LSV measurements at various rotation rates using the Koutechy-Levich (K-L) equation (Fig. S10) under both illumination and darkness. The calculated n is approximately 4, indicating a predominant 4e– pathway, which enables the direct conversion of O2 to OH–. Additionally, rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) testing (Fig. 3(d) demonstrates that the H2O2 yield remains negligibly low (< 0.2%) over a potential range of 0.2–0.8 V under illumination. This aligns well with the K-L analysis, further confirming the high selectivity of g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC for the 4e– ORR pathway. To evaluate the bifunctional catalytic activity, the OER performance of g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC was also assessed in 1 M KOH under illuminated and dark conditions. As shown in Fig. 3(e), g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC exhibits an low overpotential (η = Ej =10 – 1.23) of 497.4 mV at 10 mA cm–2 under illumination, which is close to that of 20% Pt/C+IrO2(1:1) benchmark catalyst (494.4 mV, Fig. S11 and Table S3) and is significantly lower than that of g-C3N4 (736.4 mV) and Co-N/MPC (621.4 mV). Notably, the overpotentials of all prepared catalysts under illumination were consistently lower than those measured in darkness (such as g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC(0.1:1) (583.4 mV), g-C3N4@ Co-N/MPC(0.2:1) (527.4 mV), and g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC(0.4:1) (532.4 mV), Fig. S12(a), confirming that light effectively enhances OER performance. Similar to ORR, g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC(0.3:1) possesses the lowest R ohmic (1.20 Ω cm2), R ct (19.58 Ω cm2) and Tafel slope (87.5 mV dec–1, Fig. 3(f) than that of other samples (Figs. S12(b) and S12(c), as well as Tables S3 and S5) and under illumination, confirming its superior charge transfer kinetics for the OER process and fast charge transfer at the three-phase interface. Notably, the OER performance of g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC also shows the great potential in recently reported catalysts (Fig. 3(g). To assess the bifunctional activity, the potential gap ΔE (E 10 – E 1/2) was employed as a key performance metric. As illustrated in Fig. 3(h), g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC exhibits a ΔE of 0.8864 V under illumination, which is lower than its dark-state value (0.9494 V) and marginally higher than that of 20% Pt/C+IrO2 (0.8794 V). This demonstrates its exceptional bifunctional catalytic performance. Additionally, double-layer capacitance (C dl) measurements were conducted to estimate the ECSA of all catalysts under light and dark conditions. As shown in Fig. 3(i), g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC exhibits the highest C dl (12.25 mF cm–2) under illumination, outperforming all other prepared catalysts (Fig. S13, Table S5). This suggests a higher density of electroactive sites, particularly from graphitic-N and Co-N4 coordination centers. Hence, the high ORR/OER catalytic performance may be ascribed to its hierarchically micro-mesoporous structure, which facilitates efficient mass transport and exposes a greater number of Co-N active sites, thereby promoting enhanced oxygen catalysis [58]. 3.3 Photoelectrochemical characterization and band structure analysis As shown in Fig. 4(a) , g-C3N4 have a positive slope, exhibiting an n-type semiconductor with E fb of –1.56 V (vs. Ag/AgCl). In contrast, Co-N/MPC, displaying a negative slope, is confirmed as a p-type semiconductor with an E fb of 1.61 V. The formation of a p-n heterojunction between g-C3N4 and Co-N/MPC is further substantiated by the inverted “V” shape observed in Fig. 4(c). Additionally, the valence band (VB) of Co-N/MPC and the conduction band (CB) of g-C3N4 exhibit a 0.2 V energy offset from their respective E fb values, indicating the presence of band bending at the interface [59,60]. Consequently, the CB and VB positions of g-C3N4 are determined to be –1.76 and 1.81 V, respectively [61]. Band bending at heterojunction interfaces generates a built-in electric field that drives carrier migration, suppresses recombination, and optimizes surface charge and active site environments, enhancing catalytic performance for photocatalytic and electrocatalytic applications [62,63]. To further investigate the optical properties of the synthesized materials, UV-vis absorption spectroscopy was performed (Fig. 4(d). Compared to Co-N/MPC, g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC exhibits a redshift in its absorption edge, indicative of bandgap narrowing due to the robust synergy mechanism between g-C3N4 and Co-N4 species [64]. This reduction in bandgap energy decreases the energy required for electron excitation from VB to CB, thereby facilitating the generation of additional electron-hole pairs. As well, g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC displays modified absorption characteristics in the 200–400 nm spectral region, suggesting an extended photon capture range that contributes to enhanced photo-electrocatalytic performance. Tauc plots (Fig. 4(e) reveal that the bandgap energies of g-C3N4, Co-N/MPC, and g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC are 3.00, 1.69, and 2.14 eV, respectively. As illustrated in Fig. 4(f), the resulting band structure diagram confirms the formation of a type-II p-n heterojunction, in which the energy bands of g-C3N4 and Co-N/MPC are arranged in a staggered configuration. Here, the CB of g-C3N4 is positioned at a lower energy level, while its VB resides at a higher energy level, whereas Co-N/MPC lies near the midpoint between the CB and VB of g-C3N4. Upon heterojunction formation, the energy level difference at the interface generates a built-in electric field, which drives charge carrier separation. Under illumination, incident photons with energy greater than or equal to E g excite electrons from the VB to the CB, leading to the formation of electron-hole pairs. The built-in electric field facilitates efficient electron-hole separation, directing photoexcited electrons from the CB of g-C3N4 to the Fermi level of Co-N/MPC, while holes migrate in the opposite direction [65,66]. The substantial increase in current density observed in g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC (Fig. S14) confirms that the engineered heterojunction structure effectively enhances light absorption efficiency. The efficient charge carrier separation minimizes electron-hole recombination, thereby increasing the availability of reactive charge carriers for surface electrocatalytic reactions [67]. This ultimately leads to enhanced catalytic activity for both ORR and OER reactions. 3.4 Photo-enhanced zinc-air battery/fuel cell performance To evaluate the practical applicability of g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC, a photo-enhanced zinc-air battery (ZAB) was assembled (Fig. 5(a) and systematically tested under both illuminated and dark states. In Fig. 5(b), the g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC-based ZAB achieves an open-circuit voltage (OCV) of 1.401 V under illumination, slightly exceeding its dark-state OCV of 1.395 V. Notably, a series of three connected ZABs is capable of powering a ~3 V “DHU” sign (Fig. 5(b), inset), demonstrating its potential for practical energy applications. The discharge polarization and power density curves (Fig. 5(c) reveal a peak power density of 722.5 mW cm–2 in darkness, which significantly increases to 850.7 mW cm–2 under illumination. This enhancement surpasses many reported ZABs (Fig. 5(f), Table S7), highlighting the photo-induced performance gains. Furthermore, Fig. 5(d) and Fig. S15 illustrate that the specific capacity and energy density of the g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC-based ZAB reach 718.3 mAh g–1 and 850.2 Wh kg–1 under illumination, respectively, markedly superior to its performance in darkness (609.2 mAh g–1 and 711.9 Wh kg–1). These results confirm that g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC significantly enhances energy storage potential and energy conversion efficiency under light irradiation. In addition, the rate discharge test (Fig. 5(e) further demonstrates that g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC-based ZAB exhibits a higher discharge voltage of 1.25 V at 50 mA cm–2 under illumination, surpassing its performance in darkness. Besides primary zinc-air battery, the g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC-based fuel cell also demonstrates a high power density with 411 mW cm–2 under illumination, which is sight higher than its performance in darkness (400 mW cm–2, Fig. 5(h). These results reveal high photo-enhanced ORR performance. To verify the photo-enhancement effect, the charge-discharge cycling stability was examined at 5 mA cm–2, alternating between illumination and darkness. As shown in Fig. S16, the voltage gap under illumination (0.74 V) is significantly lower than that in darkness (0.92 V). This reduction in voltage gap is attributed to the photoexcited charge carriers generated within the staggered p-n heterojunction, which effectively accelerate both the ORR during discharging and the OER during charging. More importantly, the long-term cycling performance (Fig. 5(g) demonstrates that the g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC-based ZABs maintains a stable cycling life exceeding 250 h, with a consistent voltage gap of ~0.8 V, underscoring its remarkable durability and electrochemical stability. These findings collectively confirm that the photo-enhanced ZABs exhibits superior performance, long-term operational stability, and enhanced catalytic activity, positioning g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC as a promising candidate for next-generation rechargeable metal-air batteries. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have successfully designed and synthesized a high-performance bifunctional photo-enhanced catalyst by integrating Co single-atom active sites within a g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC framework, forming a staggered p-n heterojunction. As a result, the catalyst exhibits exceptional bifunctional electrocatalytic performance, achieving a low ORR/OER overpotential gap (ΔE = 0.8864 V), a high ZAB peak power density (850.7 mW cm–2), and long-term stability exceeding 250 h. The remarkable photocatalytic enhancement observed in this study can be attributed to three key factors: (1) Increased number of active sites: the Co-N4 coordination centers act as highly efficient active sites, further enriched by N-doping and carbon defect engineering within the porous framework. (2) Hierarchical porosity ensures efficient mass transport, while the robust heterojunction structure enhances stability: the combination of hierarchical mesoporous structure and layered g-C3N4 facilitates efficient charge transport and minimizes recombination losses. (3) Extended light absorption and photoexcitation reduce reaction overpotentials by supplying additional energy. (4) The built-in electric field at the heterojunction interface promotes efficient charge separation, minimizing electron-hole recombination. This work offers a fundamental breakthrough in designing photo-enhanced bifunctional catalysts and their applications in metal-air batteries and fuel cells, bridging the gap between photocatalysis and electrocatalysis. coredata.dc:description: The sluggish kinetics of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and high over potential of oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are big challenges in the development of high-performance zinc-air batteries (ZABs) and fuel cells. In this work, we report a rational design and a simple fabrication strategy of a photo-enhanced Co single-atom catalyst (SAC) comprising g-C3N4 coupled with cobalt-nitrogen-doped hierarchical mesoporous carbon (Co-N/MPC), forming a staggered p-n heterojunction that effectively improves charge separation and enhances electrocatalytic activity. The incorporation of Co SACs and g-C3N4 synergistically optimizes the photogenerated electron-hole pair separation, significantly boosting the intrinsic ORR-OER duplex activity. Under illumination, g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC exhibits an outstanding ORR half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.841 V (vs. RHE) in 0.1 mol L–1 KOH and a low OER overpotential of 497.4 mV (vs. RHE) at 10 mA cm–2 in 1 mol L–1 KOH. Notably, the catalyst achieves an exceptional peak power density of 850.7 mW cm–2 in ZABs and of 411 mW cm–2 even in H2-air fuel cell. In addition, g-C3N4@Co-N/MPC-based ZABs also show remarkable cycling stability exceeding 250 h. The advanced photo-induced charge separation at the p-n heterojunction facilitates faster electron transfer kinetics, and the mass transport owing to hierarchical mesoporous structure of Co-N-C, thereby reducing the overpotential and enhancing the overall energy conversion efficiency. This work provides a new perspective on designing next-generation of single-atom dispersed oxygen reaction catalysts, paving the way for high-performance photo-enhanced energy storage and conversion systems.
